speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the behavior issues you're experiencing at school and at home?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's just that sometimes I feel like I don't have to do what I'm told, and I don't like it when people try to tell me what to do. My teacher says I'm being really stubborn, but I just don't see why I have to follow all the rules all the time."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about what happens when you feel like you don't have to follow the rules? Do you get angry, upset, or frustrated?

speaker: Patient
text: "I get really mad, I guess. I don't know why, but it just feels unfair that I have to listen to everyone else all the time. My mom says it's okay to disagree, but sometimes I feel like I'm being really stubborn, like she said. It's just hard to follow all the rules all the time."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when you feel like you're being stubborn? Is it usually in response to something specific, like a particular rule or situation?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't know, it just feels like sometimes I don't want to do what I'm told, and I'll say things like 'You're not the boss of me' or 'You can't make me.' I don't know why I say those things, but it just feels like I'm being really honest, I guess."

speaker: Doctor
text: It sounds like you're struggling with asserting your independence and expressing your feelings in a healthy way. Can you tell me more about what happens when you feel like you're being told what to do, and you're not sure how to respond?

speaker: Patient
text: "Honestly, I don't really know how to respond when I feel like I'm being told what to do. Sometimes I just say what I said before, like 'You're not the boss of me.' But other times, I'll just do what I want, even if it's not what the teacher or my mom says. It feels like I'm in control, even if it's not the right thing to do."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about what happens when you do what you want, even if it's not what the teacher or your mom says? Do you ever feel guilty or regret your actions afterwards?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's weird, because sometimes I feel really good about doing what I want, like I'm being strong and stuff. But other times, I'll think about it afterwards and feel kinda bad, like I did something wrong. My mom will always say 'I'm proud of you for trying to be independent, but sometimes you have to listen and follow the rules.' But it's hard to remember that when I'm in the moment."

speaker: Doctor
text: It sounds like you're struggling with a balance between independence and obedience. Can you tell me more about what happens when you think about your actions afterwards and feel bad about them?

speaker: Patient
text: "It feels like my brain just freezes for a second, and then I think about all the times I've done stuff I shouldn't have, and I feel like I'm in trouble. It's hard to remember that my mom is trying to help me, even when I'm feeling mad or frustrated."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when you feel like your brain freezes and you think about all the times you've done stuff you shouldn't have? Is it like your mind goes blank, or do you feel like you're getting a little dizzy or lightheaded? Also, can you describe what happens to your body when you feel bad about your actions afterwards? Do you feel any physical sensations, like a knot in your stomach or a lump in your throat?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't know, it's just like my brain just stops working for a second, I guess. I feel like I'm thinking really hard, but nothing's coming out. It's weird, because I'll be walking or sitting, and suddenly I'll just stop and think about all the times I did something wrong. My mom says it's like my brain is'stuck', but I don't know what that means. Sometimes I feel a little dizzy or lightheaded, but it's not like I'm actually feeling sick or anything."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when you're feeling this "stuck" in your brain? Do you feel like you're trying to remember something specific, or is it more like your mind is just going blank? And can you describe what happens to your body when you're in this state? Do you feel any physical sensations, like a knot in your stomach or a lump in your throat?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's like my brain just stops working for a second, and I'm just stuck on what I did wrong. I don't know if it's trying to remember something specific, but it feels like I'm trying to figure out why I did it. My body feels kinda... heavy, like my legs are stuck in place or something. I don't feel dizzy or anything, but it's like my brain is just really slow."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about what happens when you're trying to figure out why you did something wrong? Is it like you're trying to solve a puzzle or piece together a memory, or is it more like you're trying to understand why you felt a certain way?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's like I'm trying to put together a puzzle, but I don't know what the picture is supposed to look like. I'll think about all the things that happened, and it's like my brain is trying to find the right pieces, but they don't seem to fit. It feels like I'm trying to understand why I felt mad or frustrated, but it's hard to remember why I felt that way in the first place."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when you're trying to remember why you felt a certain way? Do you think it's because you're trying to understand your own emotions or because you're trying to figure out what triggered those emotions?

speaker: Patient
text: "Honestly, I don't know. I think it's a little bit of both, I guess. My brain just freezes for a second, and then I'm trying to figure out why I felt mad or frustrated. It's like my brain is trying to tell me something, but it's hard to hear what it's saying."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about what happens when your brain freezes for a second? Is it like you feel a sudden rush of emotions, or do you feel a sense of calm before it starts to freeze? Also, I'd like to request a neurological exam to check for any signs of neurological disorders that could be contributing to your symptoms. Can you please come with me to the exam room?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't know, it's just like... nothing happens at first, and then it's like my brain just stops working, I guess. It's hard to explain, but it's like my thoughts just get stuck and I'm left with this feeling of... of being stuck, I think."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Okay, I think I understand what you're trying to say. It sounds like you're experiencing a kind of mental block or freeze that makes it hard for you to think clearly. Can you tell me more about what happens right before your brain freezes? Do you feel any sensations or emotions before it happens?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Honestly, it's hard to explain. Sometimes I'll be walking or sitting, and I'll just feel really frustrated or mad. It's like my anger is building up inside me, and then suddenly my brain just... stops. It's like I'm not even thinking anymore, I'm just kind of... stuck. I don't know, it's weird."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when you feel like your anger is building up inside you? Do you feel any physical sensations, like your heart beating faster or your muscles tensing up, before your brain freezes?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, I guess I do feel my heart beating faster sometimes. It's like my chest gets all tight and my hands get sweaty. But then my brain just... stops, and I'm not even thinking anymore. It's really weird."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about these physical sensations you experience when you feel your anger building up? Do they feel like a warning sign that your brain is about to freeze, or do they happen right before you're stuck? Also, I'd like to request an electroencephalogram (EEG) test to check for any abnormalities in your brain activity that could be contributing to your symptoms.

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't know, it's like... my body just reacts to how I'm feeling, I guess. My heart beats faster and my hands get sweaty, and then my brain just... stops. It's like my body is trying to tell me something, but I don't know what it's saying."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Okay, I think I understand what you're trying to say. It sounds like you're experiencing a strong emotional response that can cause your brain to freeze. Can you tell me more about what happens right after your brain freezes? Do you feel any sensations or emotions after it happens?" Also, REQUEST TEST: EEG
